content.text: To ensure valid, reliable, and fair assessment practices that inform teaching, improve student learning, provide accurate feedback to students and parents, and maintain integrity across both Cambridge and Indonesian assessment requirements.

content.title: Core Beliefs
content.text: Eduversal schools implement a balanced assessment philosophy that includes Assessment FOR Learning (formative assessment to support instruction), Assessment AS Learning (student self-reflection and goal setting), and Assessment OF Learning (summative assessment to measure achievement against standards). All assessments are standards-referenced, fair, transparent, and supported by timely, actionable feedback.

items.title: Assessment FOR Learning (Formative)
points: Assessment used during learning to diagnose needs, adjust instruction, provide feedback
Purpose: Improve learning in real-time, not just measure it

items.title: Assessment AS Learning (Student Self-Assessment)
points: Students reflect on own learning, set goals, monitor progress
Purpose: Develop metacognition and self-regulation

items.title: Assessment OF Learning (Summative)
points: Assessment at end of unit/term/course to measure achievement against standards
Purpose: Report proficiency, certify mastery, inform decisions (promotion, graduation)

items.title: Standards-Referenced
points: All assessments aligned to clear learning objectives (Cambridge, Indonesian CP, SLOs)
Students assessed against standards, not against each other (criterion-referenced, not norm-referenced)

items.title: Fair and Equitable
points: Assessments accessible to all students (accommodations for EAL, SEN as needed)
Multiple measures used (tests, projects, presentations, portfolios - not just exams)
Bias minimized (culturally responsive, language-appropriate, diverse examples)

items.title: Transparent
points: Assessment criteria (rubrics, mark schemes) shared with students before assessment
Students understand what constitutes quality work
Grades based on evidence, not effort or behavior (character/effort reported separately)

items.title: Timely and Actionable Feedback
points: Feedback provided promptly (within 1-2 weeks for major assessments)
Feedback specific, constructive, and actionable (tells students what to improve and how)
Students given opportunities to apply feedback (revisions, re-assessments when appropriate)

items.title: Integrated with Instruction
points: Assessment data used to inform teaching decisions (re-teach, differentiate, accelerate)
Teachers collaborate to analyze data and improve practice (PLCs)

content.title: Balanced Assessment System
content.text: Eduversal Partner Schools employ a comprehensive assessment system balancing multiple types and purposes.

content.title: Assessment Types
rows: Identify prior knowledge, readiness, learning needs
Start of year, start of unit
Monitor progress, provide feedback, adjust teaching
Exit tickets, quizzes, draft reviews, observations, self-assessments
End of unit, mid-term, end of term
Track progress toward annual goals, compare to external standards
EASE tests, Cambridge Progression Tests, internal common assessments
Cambridge Checkpoint, IGCSE, AS/A Level; ANBK

content.text: Coordinate assessments across subjects and grades to avoid student overload and ensure adequate time for teaching, learning, and feedback.

content.title: Term 1 (July-December)
rows: Summative assessment of Term 1A content (first half of term)
Summative assessment of full Term 1 content

content.title: Term 2 (January-June)
rows: Check for learning retention, re-teach as needed
Cambridge Mock Exams (for IGCSE, AS, A Level students)
Practice under exam conditions, identify gaps before May/June exams
Summative assessment of full year content

items: 2 weeks' notice: Exam schedule published (dates, times, subjects, rooms)
Study guides provided: Teachers distribute review materials, key topics, practice questions
No new content: Week before exams reserved for review, practice, clarification (no introducing new units)
Exam prep sessions: Optional after-school tutoring or review sessions
Timetable staggered: Maximum 2 exams per day per student (avoid overload)
Breaks between exams: Minimum 1 hour (students can rest, eat, review)
Quiet zones: Library, study areas designated for quiet review during free periods
Invigilation: Exams proctored by teachers (not teaching that subject to avoid bias)
Accommodations: Students with IEPs/access arrangements receive approved support (extra time, separate room, etc.)
Prompt marking: Teachers aim to return marked exams within 1 week
Exam review sessions: Teachers go over exams with students, discuss correct answers, common errors, learning opportunities
Feedback: Written comments on exams indicating strengths and areas for improvement

content.text: Provide ongoing feedback during learning to help students improve before summative assessments.

items.title: Exit Tickets (3-2-1, One Minute Paper)
points: Process: At end of lesson, students write brief response on index card or digital form
Use: Teacher reviews, identifies misconceptions, adjusts next lesson
Frequency: 2-3 times per week

items.title: Think-Pair-Share
points: Process: Pose question; students think individually (1 min), discuss with partner (2 min), share with class
Use: Checks understanding, encourages participation, identifies gaps in real-time
Frequency: Multiple times per lesson

items.title: Thumbs Up/Down/Sideways (or digital polling)
points: Process: Teacher asks confidence check; students signal or vote via app (Kahoot, Mentimeter, Google Forms)
Use: Quick check of class-wide understanding; differentiate next steps
Frequency: 1-2 times per lesson

items.title: Draft Reviews and Peer Feedback
points: Process: Students submit draft; receive feedback from teacher or peer using rubric; revise before final submission
Use: Improves quality of final work, teaches students to self-assess and give constructive feedback
Frequency: For major writing assignments, projects

items.title: Observation and Anecdotal Notes
points: Process: Teacher observes students during independent work, group activities, discussions; records notes
Use: Informs teaching, identifies students needing support or extension
Frequency: Ongoing; teachers keep notes per student

items.title: Self-Assessment and Reflection
points: Process: Students assess own work against rubric or criteria, identify strengths and areas for growth, set goals
Use: Develops metacognition, ownership of learning
Frequency: After major assessments, end of unit

items: Specific: Identifies exactly what was done well (not just "Good job")
Actionable: Tells students what to improve and how
Timely: Provided while student still working on topic or skill (within 1-2 weeks)
Balanced: Acknowledge strengths AND identify areas for growth
Goal-Oriented: Connected to learning objectives and student's individual goals
Written comments: On student work (margins, end comments)
Rubrics: Checked indicators with brief comments
Verbal feedback: During conferences, in-class check-ins
Audio/Video feedback: Recorded comments (especially useful for detailed feedback on essays or projects)
Peer feedback: Structured peer review using protocols or rubrics

content.text: Measure student achievement against standards at end of learning period.

items.title: Traditional Tests/Exams
points: Format: Multiple choice, short answer, essay questions
Best for: Assessing knowledge recall, comprehension, analysis
Design: Align questions to learning objectives; include range of difficulty; use Bloom's Taxonomy levels; clear instructions and adequate time

items.title: Performance Tasks
points: Format: Students demonstrate skills or create product (lab experiment, oral presentation, debate, drama performance, art portfolio)
Best for: Assessing application, creativity, practical skills, communication
Design: Authentic (real-world relevance); clear task description and rubric; opportunities for planning, practice, feedback

items.title: Projects
points: Format: Extended inquiry or creation over several weeks (research paper, science fair project, documentary film, engineering design challenge)
Best for: Assessing synthesis, creativity, research skills, independence, collaboration
Design: Scaffolded checkpoints (proposal, outline, draft, final); rubric addressing both process and product; balance individual accountability with collaboration

items.title: Portfolios
points: Format: Curated collection of student work over time showing growth and achievement
Best for: Assessing progress, reflection, range of skills
Design: Clear selection criteria; reflective component; standards-aligned (portfolio mapped to learning objectives)

content.title: Assessment Quality Checklist
content.text: Before administering summative assessment, teachers verify:

items: Alignment: All questions/tasks aligned to taught content and learning objectives
Coverage: Assessment covers breadth of unit (not just one topic)
Validity: Assessment measures what it intends to measure
Reliability: Assessment would yield consistent results if given again or marked by different teacher
Fairness: No bias; accessible to all students with appropriate accommodations
Clarity: Instructions clear, questions unambiguous
Time: Adequate time for students to complete (not rushed)
Rubric/Mark Scheme: Prepared in advance, shared with students

content.text: Moderation is the process through which teachers collaboratively review student work to ensure that marking is fair, accurate, and consistently aligned to agreed standards across teachers, classes, and time. Moderation protects the integrity of assessment and ensures that students are graded according to the same expectations.

items.title: Pre-Assessment Standardization (Before Marking)
points: When: Before teachers begin marking major assessment
Select anchor samples: Choose 3-5 student work samples representing range of quality (high, medium, low)
Independent marking: Each teacher marks anchor samples independently using rubric
Compare marks: Teachers share their marks and reasoning
Discuss discrepancies: If marks differ significantly (>10%), discuss interpretation of rubric, calibrate understanding
Reach consensus: Agree on marks for anchor samples; these become benchmark

items.title: During-Marking Moderation (Spot Checks)
points: When: While marking is underway (halfway through marking class set)
Sample exchange: Teachers exchange 5-10 scripts with colleague teaching same subject/grade
Blind re-mark: Colleague re-marks without seeing original marks
Compare: If marks within 5-10% consistency confirmed; if discrepancy >10% discuss and adjust
Adjust if needed: If systemic issue found, adjust marks for all students

items.title: Post-Marking Moderation (Final Review)
points: When: After all marking completed, before grades finalized
Data review: HOD or Academic Coordinator reviews grade distribution, checks for anomalies
Sample review: HOD reviews sample of marked work from each teacher
Feedback to teachers: If concerns found, provide feedback and request adjustments

content.title: Moderation for Cambridge Coursework
content.text: For Cambridge subjects with teacher-assessed coursework (e.g., Art & Design portfolio, Science practical skills), schools must conduct internal moderation before submitting marks to Cambridge (Section 3.13).

items: Teacher assesses student work using Cambridge mark schemes
Internal moderation: HOD or experienced colleague reviews sample (highest, middle, lowest achieving students)
Adjust marks if needed: Ensure alignment with Cambridge standards
Submit marks to Cambridge: Via Cambridge International Direct
External moderation by Cambridge: Cambridge selects sample to review; may adjust school's marks up or down for all students if discrepancy found

content.text: Academic grades reflect student achievement against curriculum standards. Character and effort indicators (such as participation, organization, homework completion, and perseverance) are reported separately and are not included in the calculation of academic grades.

items: Official Cambridge grades: A*, A, B, C, D, E, F, G, U (or 9-1 scale for some subjects)
Assigned by Cambridge based on external exam performance (and coursework if applicable)
School-based grades: Schools use predicted grades or percentage/letter grades aligned to Cambridge standards

content.title: Primary and Lower Secondary (Pre-IGCSE)
content.text: Schools design own grading scale aligned to Cambridge learning objectives.

items: Scale: 0-100 (percentage)
Minimum Passing Grade (KKM - Kriteria Ketuntasan Minimal): Set by school for each subject, typically 70-75
90-100 = Sangat Baik (Excellent)
80-89 = Baik (Good)
70-79 = Cukup (Satisfactory)
Below 70 = Kurang (Needs Improvement; may require remediation)

content.title: Profil Pelajar Pancasila Reporting
content.text: Separate from subject grades.

items: MB (Mulai Berkembang) - Beginning to Develop
BSH (Berkembang Sesuai Harapan) - Developing as Expected
SAB (Sudah Berkembang) - Well Developed
SB (Sangat Berkembang) - Highly Developed
Each of 6 Profil Pelajar Pancasila dimensions rated separately (Beriman, Berkebinekaan Global, Bergotong Royong, Mandiri, Bernalar Kritis, Kreatif)

content.title: Character/Effort Grades (Separate from Academic Grades)
content.text: Academic grades reflect achievement against standards; character/effort grades reflect habits, behaviors, attitudes.

items: Participation: Engages in class discussions, asks questions, contributes to group work
Homework Completion: Submits assignments on time, demonstrates effort
Organization: Comes prepared with materials, keeps work neat and organized
Perseverance: Persists when work is challenging, seeks help when needed
Respect: Treats others respectfully, follows classroom norms
E (Excellent): Consistently demonstrates positive habits
S (Satisfactory): Usually demonstrates positive habits
N (Needs Improvement): Inconsistently demonstrates positive habits; improvement plan needed

content.text: Communicate student progress to students and parents clearly, accurately, and in ways that support continued learning. EduNav is the primary platform for recording assessment data, reporting grades, and communicating student progress to parents and students.

items: Mid-Term Progress Reports (Informal): Week 8-10 of each term; email or EduNav message; content indicates 'on track,' 'excelling,' or 'concern' for each subject
End-of-Term Report Cards (Formal): Week 20 (Term 1) and Week 24 (Term 2); multi-page printed or digital report card with detailed grades, teacher comments, attendance, character/effort

items.title: Student and School Information
points: Student name, grade, homeroom teacher
School name, logo, academic year
Reporting period (Term 1 or Term 2)

items.title: Cambridge Subjects Section
points: Subjects listed (English, Math, Sciences, Humanities, Electives)
Grades (percentage or letter grade; predicted Cambridge grade if applicable)
Teacher comments (2-3 sentences per subject): Strengths, areas for growth, recommendations

items.title: Indonesian National Subjects Section
points: Subjects listed (Bahasa Indonesia, PPKn, Religion, Mulok)
Grades (0-100 scale)
Teacher comments (in Bahasa Indonesia)

items.title: Profil Pelajar Pancasila Competencies
points: Six dimensions (Beriman, Berkebinekaan Global, Bergotong Royong, Mandiri, Bernalar Kritis, Kreatif)
Rating for each (MB, BSH, SAB, SB)
Overall Profil Pelajar Pancasila comment

items.title: Character and Effort
points: Indicators (Participation, Homework, Organization, Perseverance, Respect)
Rating (E, S, N)

items.title: Attendance
points: Days Present / Total Days
Absences: Excused, unexcused, late arrivals
Comment if attendance concern

items.title: Co-Curricular Participation
points: Activities (clubs, sports, service)
Brief note on contribution

items.title: Homeroom Teacher Overall Comment
points: Holistic summary (academic progress, social-emotional development, character growth)
Goals for next term
Parent partnership: How parents can support at home

items.title: Signatures
points: Homeroom teacher, Principal/GM, Parent/Guardian (parent signs to acknowledge receipt)

items: IEP students' reports include progress toward IEP goals (separate section or addendum)
Grades may reflect modified standards (if applicable), clearly indicated
Comments reference accommodations and support provided

content.text: Complement written reports with face-to-face dialogue, answer parent questions, co-create support plans.

items: Term 1: Week 20 (after Term 1 report cards distributed)
Mid-Year (Optional/As Needed): Week 10 of Term 2 (for students with concerns)
Term 2: Week 24 (after final report cards; often combined with graduation/end-of-year celebration)
10-15 minute appointments per family (longer for students with IEPs or significant concerns)
Student-led conferences (optional): Student presents own work and progress to parents with teacher facilitating (especially effective Grades 7+)

items.title: Welcome and Relationship Building (1-2 min)
points: Teacher greets family warmly, thanks them for attending
Brief positive opening

items.title: Review Academic Progress (5-7 min)
points: Share report card, highlight strengths
Discuss areas for growth with specific examples
Show student work samples (tests, projects, writing)
Answer parent questions about grades, assessments

items.title: Social-Emotional and Character Development (2-3 min)
points: Discuss student's behavior, participation, friendships, wellbeing
Note Profil Pelajar Pancasila competencies and character growth

items.title: Goal Setting and Action Plan (2-3 min)
points: Collaboratively set 1-2 goals for next term (academic and/or behavioral)
Student will: e.g., complete homework daily, ask questions when confused
Teacher will: e.g., provide extra practice materials, check in weekly
Parent will: e.g., monitor homework completion, ensure adequate sleep

items.title: Closing (1 min)
points: Summarize agreements
Thank family for partnership
Provide contact information for follow-up

items: Review student data (grades, assessments, attendance, behavior)
Prepare talking points (2-3 strengths, 1-2 areas for growth)
Gather work samples
Anticipate parent questions/concerns
Review report card before conference
Prepare questions
Bring concerns or observations from home

subsections.title: Use of Assessment Data to Inform Instruction

content.text: Assessment is not an endpoint; it's a tool to improve teaching and learning.

content.title: Data Analysis Process (Professional Learning Communities)
content.text: Professional Learning Communities (PLCs) are teams of teachers (same subject, same grade, or cross-grade) meeting regularly to analyze student data, share strategies, and improve practice.

items.title: Review Data (15 min)
points: Teachers bring assessment data (recent quiz, unit test, formative assessments)
Identify patterns: Strengths (which objectives mastered), Gaps (which objectives struggled), Outliers (students significantly above or below average)

items.title: Analyze Root Causes (10 min)
points: Why did students struggle?
Insufficient instructional time? Concept too abstract? Language barriers (EAL)? Prerequisite skills missing? Assessment unclear or too difficult?

items.title: Plan Interventions (15 min)
points: For whole class: Re-teach concept using different approach (more visuals, hands-on activity, real-world example)
For small groups: Targeted intervention during class or after school
For individuals: One-on-one tutoring, modified assignment, referral to EAL/SEN support

items.title: Share Strategies (10 min)
points: Teachers share what worked well (successful lesson, effective assessment, differentiation strategy)
Borrow ideas from colleagues

items.title: Set Goals for Next Meeting (5 min)
points: Commit to trying new strategy
Plan next assessment to monitor progress
Schedule follow-up

content.title: Example 1: Grade 8 Math (Algebra Unit)
content.text: Root Cause: Instruction moved too quickly; students needed more practice with scaffolded problems before tackling complex multi-step equations.

items: Whole Class: Reteach multi-step equations with explicit step-by-step modeling; use color-coding
Small Group: Pull 10 students for additional practice during independent work time
Individual: 3 students referred to after-school math support for foundational gaps
Re-Assessment: Quiz given 1 week after intervention; 85% now score above 70%

content.title: Example 2: Grade 10 IGCSE English (Essay Writing)
content.text: EASE Cycle 2 writing scores show 40% of Grade 10 students below proficiency in argumentative writing.

items: Curriculum Adjustment: Add 2-week unit on argumentative writing (model essays, thesis statements, claim-evidence-analysis structure)
Scaffolding: Provide graphic organizers (essay outline template)
Peer Review: Students exchange drafts, give feedback using rubric
EAL Support: Push-in support during writing lessons; pre-teach academic vocabulary
Re-Assessment: Next essay assignment (1 month later); 70% now proficient or above

content.title: Teacher Professional Development Based on Data
content.text: DTP (Development of Teaching Proficiency): Network-wide professional development program addressing gaps identified through assessment data, Appraisal results, and PLC discussions.
Cultivate culture of honesty, original thinking, and proper attribution; prevent and address academic dishonesty.

items: Plagiarism: Using someone else's words, ideas, or work without proper citation (includes copying from internet, books, peers)
Cheating: Using unauthorized materials or assistance during assessments (cheat sheets, copying answers, using phone)
Collusion: Unauthorized collaboration (working together on individual assignment and submitting similar work)
Fabrication: Making up data, sources, or citations
Facilitation: Helping another student cheat (sharing answers, letting someone copy)
AI Misuse: Submitting AI-generated work without attribution or using AI inappropriately

items.title: Explicit Teaching
points: Primary (Grades 1-6): Age-appropriate lessons on copying vs. own work, paraphrasing, giving credit
Secondary (Grades 7-12): Formal instruction on citation styles (MLA, APA, Chicago), paraphrasing vs. quoting vs. summarizing, integrating sources

items.title: Assignment Design
points: Process-based assignments: Require drafts, outlines, research logs
Unique prompts: Change essay questions/project topics each year
In-class components: Include in-class writing, presentations, or checkpoints
Authentic tasks: Real-world problems or creative prompts less likely to have ready-made answers online

items.title: Technology Use
points: Plagiarism detection software: Turnitin, Grammarly Plagiarism Checker, or similar
AI detection tools: GPTZero, Turnitin AI detector (use judiciously; not 100% accurate; combine with other evidence)

items.title: Classroom Culture
points: Value learning over grades: Emphasize growth, effort, improvement
Normalize asking for help: Make it clear that seeking teacher/tutor assistance is encouraged
Honor code or integrity pledge: Students sign a commitment to honesty at start of year

items.title: Step 1: Gather Evidence
points: Teacher documents concern (suspicious similarity, unusual change in writing quality, identical answers to peer)
Run plagiarism check or compare work samples

items.title: Step 2: Private Conversation with Student
points: Teacher meets with student privately, presents evidence
Ask student to explain (give benefit of doubt; may be misunderstanding)

items.title: Step 3: Determine Violation Level and Consequence
points: Minor Violation (First offense, unintentional): Educational conversation, redo assignment, warning recorded
Moderate Violation (Intentional or significant scope): Zero or reduced grade, parent notification, reflection essay, recorded in student file
Major Violation (Serious, repeated, or high-stakes): Zero on assignment/exam, referral to Principal/GM, parent meeting, may impact grade or eligibility for honors

items.title: Step 4: Documentation
points: Teacher completes Academic Integrity Incident Report
Includes: Description of violation, evidence, student response, consequence, follow-up plan
Stored in student file and discipline records

content.title: Cambridge-Specific Malpractice
content.text: For Cambridge exams or coursework: Follow Section 3.10 procedures (must report to Cambridge; Cambridge investigates and imposes sanctions).

content.title: AI and Academic Integrity Guidelines
content.text: AI tools may be used to support learning for tasks such as idea generation, research support, language development, and proofreading. However, students must always submit work that reflects their own understanding and original thinking.

items: Brainstorming: Generate topic ideas, outline structures
Grammar/spelling check: Grammarly, spell-checkers for proofreading
Translation support: Translate key terms or phrases for comprehension (EAL students)
Research assistant: Ask AI to explain difficult concepts, suggest resources (but verify accuracy)
Writing essays or responses: AI writes content submitted as student's own work
Solving problems: AI solves math problems, science questions, etc., and student copies without understanding
Creating projects/presentations: AI generates slides, posters, artwork submitted as student's original creation

content.text: Guideline: If the assignment assesses students' writing, thinking, or problem-solving, AI should not do that work. AI can support process but not replace student's intellectual effort.
Fair assessment means giving every student opportunity to demonstrate what they know and can do, which sometimes requires different conditions or formats.

content.title: Accommodations (Do Not Change Standards)
content.text: For Students with IEPs or Documented Needs:

items.title: Time
points: Extended time (typically 25% extra)
Frequent breaks (5-10 min break every 30-45 min)

items.title: Setting
points: Separate quiet room (minimize distractions)
Small group setting (less anxiety)
Preferential seating (front of room, away from window)

items.title: Presentation
points: Enlarged print (font size 14-18)
Read-aloud (teacher or software reads questions to student)
Simplified language (reword complex instructions without changing content)
Visual aids (graphic organizers, diagrams)

items.title: Response
points: Scribe (student dictates answers; scribe writes)
Word processor (typing instead of handwriting)
Oral response (student answers verbally instead of writing)
Dictation software (speech-to-text)

items: Identification: Student assessed by psychologist/specialist; need documented in IEP
Approval: Accommodations approved by Academic Coordinator/SEN Coordinator
Implementation: Teachers implement accommodations for all assessments (classroom tests and Cambridge exams if approved by Cambridge)
Documentation: Accommodations noted in student file; evidence of use maintained

content.title: Differentiated Assessment (Adjust to Readiness/Interest)
content.text: For All Students (Not Just SEN):

items.title: Choice Boards
points: Students choose how to demonstrate learning from menu of options
Example (Grade 9 Science - Cell Unit): Option A: Written test; Option B: Create 3D cell model with oral explanation; Option C: Produce video explaining cell structure
All options assess same learning objectives but cater to different strengths

items.title: Tiered Assessments
points: Same learning objective, different complexity levels
Example (Grade 8 Math - Fractions): Tier 1 (Approaching): Like denominators; Tier 2 (Meeting): Unlike denominators; Tier 3 (Exceeding): Word problems with multiple operations

items.title: Product Options
points: Allow students to choose format (essay, presentation, poster, video, podcast, etc.) as long as content requirements met

content.text: Compare student performance to external standards, track growth over time, inform school improvement.

content.title: EASE (Evaluation of Achievement Standardized Exam)
content.text: Eduversal network-wide standardized assessment administered 4x/year for all students Grades 1-12.

items: Literacy: Reading comprehension, writing
Numeracy: Mathematical reasoning, problem-solving
Subject-Specific Content: Science, social studies (varies by grade)
Online platform (Edutama/EASE system)
Scheduled windows: Week 10 (Cycle 1), Week 4 (Cycle 2), Week 11 (Cycle 3), Week 18 (Cycle 4)
Proctored by teachers (not high-stakes; classroom-based)
Individual Student Reports: Performance by skill/standard; growth from previous cycle
Class Reports: Aggregate data for teacher (objectives mastered vs. needing reteaching)
School Reports: Overall school performance; comparison to Eduversal network average
Eduversal Network Reports: Benchmarking across all 15+ partner schools
Individual Student Reports: Question-by-question breakdown, strengths/weaknesses, comparison to class/school/national average
Class Reports: High/low achievers, topic-by-topic evaluation, class strengths
Validity Reports: Question quality analysis for continuous improvement
Topic Evaluation Reports: Subject-specific performance vs network schools
Certificates of Achievement: Top 3 students per subject (motivation/recognition)
Quick results: Latihan.id dashboard (immediately after test)
Comprehensive reports: Edunav > EASE > EASE Keys and Results

content.title: Cambridge Progression Tests
content.text: Optional diagnostic tests from Cambridge for Grades 7-9 (Lower Secondary) in English, Math, Science.

items: Assess readiness for next stage (particularly IGCSE)
Identify strengths and gaps
Benchmark against international standards
Schools may administer annually (typically end of year, Week 16-18)
NOT high-stakes; not reported on transcript

content.title: ANBK (Asesmen Nasional Berbasis Komputer)
content.text: Indonesian national assessment (Section 2.16). Sample of students in Grades 5, 8, 11.

items: Literacy and Numeracy (AKM - Asesmen Kompetensi Minimum)
Character (Survei Karakter - student wellbeing, P8 values)
Learning Environment (Survei Lingkungan Belajar - teacher and principal complete)
School-level results only (not individual student grades)
Results published in Rapor Pendidikan (national education report card)
Comparison to national, provincial, and similar schools
Results inform school improvement planning and quality management discussions with Yayasan and Ministry

subsections.title: Reporting to Universities and Transcript Management

content.text: Provide accurate, comprehensive academic records for university admission, scholarships, and transfers.

items: Student Information: Name, date of birth, student ID
School Information: School name, address, curriculum type (Cambridge + Indonesian)
Academic Record: Grades for all courses taken (Grades 9-12 typically); course titles, credit hours, grades, year taken; separate sections for Cambridge and Indonesian subjects
Standardized Test Results: Cambridge IGCSE, AS, A Level results; ANBK participation noted
GPA (Grade Point Average): Calculated on a 4.0 scale; weighted or unweighted (clearly indicated)
Class Rank (Optional): If the school ranks students
Graduation Date: Expected or actual
School Profile: Summary of school curriculum, grading scale, available courses, university outcomes
Official transcripts: Sealed envelope with school stamp, or sent electronically via secure platform
Unofficial transcripts: Student/parent may view via EduNav; not valid for applications
Processing time: 3-5 business days
Fee may apply (especially for rush requests or international mailing)

content.title: Predicted Grades for University Applications
content.text: Predicted grades are professional teacher judgments indicating the grade a student is most likely to achieve in their final Cambridge examinations. They are confidential and based on evidence such as class assessments, mock examinations, coursework, and teacher professional judgement.

items: Teacher Assessment: Subject teacher predicts the grade based on mock exams, coursework, and classwork performance
Review: Principal/Academic Coordinator reviews predictions for consistency
Letter: School issues official predicted grades letter on school letterhead, signed by Principal
Confidentiality: Predictions shared with universities but typically not with students/parents (to avoid pressure)

content.text: Accuracy Imperative: Predictions should be realistic; over-predicting harms students and damages school credibility.

content.title: Letters of Recommendation
content.text: Provide qualitative assessment of student's academic abilities, character, potential.

items: Student requests recommendation from teacher(s) and/or counselor (typically 2-3 letters required)
Student provides: Resume/CV, personal statement draft, university list, deadline
Teacher writes letter addressing: how they know student, academic strengths, character qualities, comparison to peers, endorsement
Teacher submits directly to university (confidential; student typically waives right to read)
Students request letters at least 4-6 weeks before deadline

subsections.title: Assessment Policy Review and Continuous Improvement

content.text: Assessment practices evolve based on research, student needs, stakeholder feedback.

content.title: Annual Assessment Policy Review
content.text: When: End of academic year (May-June). Who: Assessment Committee (Academic Coordinator, HODs, selected teachers, SEN Coordinator, Principal/GM).

items.title: Data Review
points: Student achievement trends (are students improving year-over-year?)
Assessment reliability and validity (are assessments measuring what they should?)
Moderation effectiveness (are marks fair and consistent?)
Use of accommodations (are students receiving needed support?)

items.title: Stakeholder Feedback
points: Teacher survey (workload, clarity of grading policies, moderation usefulness)
Student survey (fairness of assessments, clarity of expectations, usefulness of feedback)
Parent survey (communication of grades, understanding of reports)

items.title: Research and Best Practices
points: Review educational research on assessment (new strategies, tools)
Benchmark against other schools (Eduversal network, international schools)

items.title: Identify Improvements
points: Update grading scales, rubrics, reporting formats if needed
Add new assessment types (e.g., incorporate more performance tasks)
Improve turnaround time for feedback
Strengthen moderation processes

items.title: Revise Policy
points: Update Assessment Policy document
Communicate changes to staff, students, parents

items.title: Professional Development
points: Plan PD sessions for teachers on assessment practices (designing quality assessments, effective feedback, using data)

content.title: Accreditation Alignment
content.text: Assessment practices reviewed during:

items: CIS/WASC accreditation self-study (Section 18) - assessment is major focus area
Eduversal Supervisi visits (Section 2.21) - quality assurance includes assessment review

content.text: The Appraisal Program evaluates teaching quality through:

items: Subject Appraisals: 35-45 min classroom observations across core subjects
School Appraisal: Evaluation across five domains (School Development, Management & Leadership, Subject Departments, Olympiad & Educational Technology, Curriculum/Teaching/Assessment)
Conducted by the Eduversal Appraisal Team annually
Results inform professional development planning (DTP)

content.text: All assessment data, records, and reports are handled confidentially in accordance with Indonesian data protection regulations and Eduversal policy.

items: Assessment Policy (formative, summative, moderation, grading, reporting, integrity)
Academic Integrity Policy
Accommodations and Differentiation Guidelines
AI Usage Guidelines
Sample assessments (tests, rubrics, project descriptions) from each subject/grade
Assessment blueprints (alignment to standards)
Moderation cover sheets and protocols
EASE reports (individual, class, school, network)
Cambridge results (Checkpoint, IGCSE, AS/A Level) - past 3 years
ANBK results (school-level)
PLC meeting notes with data analysis
Report card templates (Cambridge subjects, Indonesian subjects, Profil Pelajar Pancasila, character)
Sample report cards (redacted for privacy)
Parent-Teacher Conference schedules and notes
Transcripts (official and unofficial formats)
Academic Integrity Incident Reports (anonymized summaries)
Plagiarism detection reports (Turnitin summaries)
Student integrity pledges
IEP/accommodation documentation
Access arrangement approvals (Cambridge)
Implementation logs
Assessment-focused PD session materials
Teacher training on rubrics, moderation, feedback

content.text: This section aligns with:

items: Cambridge Assessment Standards: Internal and external moderation procedures; coursework integrity; secure exam administration; fair and valid assessment
Indonesian Curriculum Standards: Assessment aligned to Capaian Pembelajaran (CP); Profil Pelajar Pancasila competency assessment; reporting requirements
CIS Standards: Teaching & Assessing for Learning (assessment drives instruction, valid and reliable, fair and ethical, communicated clearly)
WASC Category B: Curriculum, Instruction, and Assessment (Criterion B3 - assessment practices valid, reliable, equitable; results used to improve learning)
Eduversal SLOs: Assessment measures progress toward SLOs; SLO-linked reporting to parents
